Award.AwardTitle: Birational Geometry of Moduli Spaces and Bridgeland Stability
Award.AbstractNarration:
Important systems in many areas of science and engineering, ranging from evolutionary biology to physics and from cryptography to computer science, can be described by systems of polynomial equations. Algebraic geometry studies solutions of such polynomial systems. Often, the solutions of these systems vary in a continuous manner depending on parameters in the defining equations of these systems, leading to parametrized spaces of solutions. A difficult-to-study system may lie in the same parameter space as a system that is easy to solve, allowing one to deduce geometric constraints on the difficult system. This project studies the geometry of some parameter spaces that are ubiquitous in mathematics and physics, so-called moduli spaces of vector bundles and moduli spaces of curves. The research computes geometric invariants of these spaces by relating them to simpler spaces. A recent breakthrough called Bridgeland stability has allowed computation of many of the invariants that were previously inaccessible. This research project aims to extend these results. In addition, the project contributes to training the next generation of researchers in mathematics through the involvement of graduate students and postdoctoral associates in the research.

Bridgeland stability conditions provide a new tool for studying the geometry of moduli spaces of sheaves. This project aims to combine Bridgeland stability conditions with recent advances in birational geometry to study longstanding questions about the geometry of moduli spaces of sheaves on surfaces and moduli spaces of curves. These moduli spaces play a central role in many branches of mathematics. Consequently, it is crucial to understand their cohomology and birational geometry. The project involves three parts. First, building on work with collaborators, the PI will study the birational geometry of the moduli spaces of sheaves on surfaces. He will compute their birational invariants such as the cones of ample, movable, and effective divisors, concentrating on Hirzebruch surfaces, del Pezzo surfaces, and certain surfaces of general type. Second, the PI will study resolutions of ideal sheaves of points and curves in projective space in terms of other exceptional collections. In the case of the plane, the geometry is significantly simplified if one resolves sheaves in terms of an appropriately chosen exceptional collection; this work will apply the same ideas to sheaves on higher-dimensional projective spaces. Third, the PI will continue collaborative projects on the effective cones of higher codimension cycles on moduli spaces of curves, the Kawamata-Morrison Cone Conjecture, and extremality properties of cycles in homogeneous spaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many processes in life are modeled by systems of polynomial equations. Algebraic geometry studies solutions of polynomial systems. Often, the solutions of these systems vary in a continuous manner depending on the defining equations of these systems, leading to parameter spaces of solutions. A difficult-to-study system may lie in the same parameter space as a system which is easy to solve, allowing one to deduce geometric constraints on the difficult system. In this project, the PI studied the geometry of some of the parameter spaces that are most ubiquitous in mathematics and physics called moduli spaces of vector bundles and moduli spaces of curves. He computed geometric invariants of these spaces using a recent breakthrough called Bridgeland stability conditions. 

 

Intellectual Merit: During the grant the PI published 17 papers. The PI resolved several long-standing questions relating to the geometry of curves on surfaces  and moduli spaces of sheaves on surfaces. 

First, building on joint work with Arcara, Bertram, Huizenga and Woolf, the PI studied the birational geometry of the moduli spaces of sheaves on surfaces. In joint work with Jack Huizenga, the PI computed the ample cones of these moduli spaces of sheaves on surfaces. Then the PI and Huizenga studied the invariants of a general stable sheaf on a surface. We determined the cohomology of the general stable sheaf on a Hirzebruch surface and classified the moduli spaces where the general sheaf is globally generated. Using these results we were able to classify the stable sheaves on Hirzebruch surfaces for any polarization. 
In joint work with Matthew Woolf, the PI studied the topology of these spaces and showed that the complexity of these spaces (as measured by Betti numbers) stabilizes as the discriminant tends to infinity for rational surfaces.
In joint work with Eric Riedl, the PI studied the genus of curves on a very general surface of degree at least 5. We improved the celebrated Xu bounds and proved that a very general quintic surface is algebraically hyperbolic, resolving a 20-year-old conjecture of Demailly. We also studied normal bundles of rational curves on projective space and complete intersections, providing counterexamples to a long-standing conjecture of Eisenbud and Van de Ven and obtaining a simple proof that a general Fano complete intersection is separably rationally connected.

Broader Impacts: During the grant the PI graduated 5 PhD students: Seckin Adali (postdoc University of Oslo), Tim Ryan (postdoc SUNY Stony Brook), Alex Stathis (postdoc University of Georgia), Tabes Bridges (lecturer UIC) and John Kopper (postdoc Penn State). The PI is training an additional 3 PhD students, two of whom will graduate in the academic year 2019-2020. The PI trained 3 postdocs Eric Riedl (currently an assistant professor at Notre Dame), John Lesieutre (currently an assistant professor at Penn State), Matthew Woolf (currently at Google Cambridge). The PI is  supervising the postdoc Howard Nuer. 

The PI organized four conferences and workshops aimed at graduate students and postdocs on the topic of the grant. In addition, the PI taught at several summer schools and workshops for graduate students. Some of these lectures have been recorded and are available on YouTube. The PI wrote 3 survey articles on aspects of his work and edited a book of articles written by young researchers surveying the recent developments in algebraic geometry aimed at graduate students and postdocs.
